publicationStmt.publisher: The Characters that shaped the Silk Road - A Database and Digital Paleography of Tarim

history.provenance: found in Šorčuqduring T III Š 92.49

seg.seg: not passion and ignorance, and then (they asked): [7c] existence... (7) ...
how are you able to inhibit the power of passion? [8b] Four ...
[8d] The body has to be seen as loathsome[ness], the Aśubha-[meditation] must constantly be observed ...
By the practitioners the elements [of the body] have be seen [as] six-fold
[9d] (it dwells) only in such droplets. [10b] Nine to ten days he lies down ...
the (elements) [are] stuck together and all pores [are] shut. [11a] By the mother the semen ...
... like turned between two fires the suffering one dwells. [11d] Worms ...
having seen through the skin, the house of bones through the flesh. [12c] ...
the body (they turn) now, so that the wise see the (head) ... [13b]
depressed. [13d] Those who [are] restless, the self of these (thy raise?) up earlier ...
to pull the mind first towards the face. [14c] (On) the forehead between the brows ...
the woman, however, clung to the face of the man. [15b] Thereupon ...
... die Frau hingegen hing an der Gestalt des Mannes.
... the woman, on the other hand, was attached/clung(?) to the shape of the man.
(to recognize them one after the other). (Those) beings (that are good in evoking the Aśubha[-meditations]), the Yogins, are named in three ways [16a]
(As far as the Ādikārmikas [are concerned], these) dignified ones (are [named] in three ways). [16c] Some [have] the wish to see far, others [16d] ...
[18b] (But if) the one who's mind is scattered and begins to run ...

p.note: Includes strophes 7c-18c of the Tṛṣṇāvarga (III) and directly continues , but considering the small size of the fragment – two thirds of the leaf are missing – and the complexity of the subject matter – it is a description of the Aśubhabhāvanā, i.e. meditation on the impurity or the abomination of the body – much remains unclear and uncertain, and the translation must be taken as an attempt only.The German translation in 16 quotes Abhidhk VI 10a-b as a reference for ease of understanding.
The original manuscript is missing, but was the left side (about 1/4) of leaf 42 to the schnurloch.
Additions according to II, 15 fn. 11 and 12 based on a1.
Additions according to II, 16 fn. 1 based on a2.
Emendation according to 33 fn. 5 based on a4.

list.item: a1 mā eṅkl aknātsaññe tu _ṣ_p\ – kare : bhavā /// a2 me _m_akte camce_r\ eṅkalntse war_k_ṣ_a_l\ taṅtsi : śtwā /// a3 ktseñe ykāṃṣe lkāṣlya aśubh\ ṣe_k\ wa_r_a_ṣ_ṣ_alle /// a4 nīkeṃt_s\ dhatunma ṣkas yäknesa lkāṣlona /// a5 _ṣ_ṣ_aṃ cew_k\ _p_altakne : ñumeṃ śa_k\ kauṃ lya_ś_aṃ /// a6 nma ṣesa tswauwa prutkauwa po klokaśśi : mātri śū /// a7 ku wī pwārine kl· ·au – m_t\ wsa_ṣ_ṣ_aṃ lklessu 10-1 yeli /// a8 yetsesa lyel·· – – mīsasa ost astāṣṣe : /// b1 kektseñä\ ñke sp· – sk· _m_akte lkāskeṃ aiśaumy= ā /// b2 sesīnoṣo 10-3 k_use slakkari kauc āñmo ceṃt_s\ nau_ṣ\ /// b3 lsko pannatsiśä\ rupne yparwe : _p_arwān= epiṅkt= ānte /// b4 klīye rano treṅksate rūpn= eṅwentse : tū /// b5 wnolmi _t_aryā yäkne weweño_ṣ\ yogācā /// b6 rneñco : ṣemeṃt_s\ aurtse lkātsy āñme alye /// b7 stastaukkauwa āmpauwa s_p_arkauw= ere : ·ai /// b8 cwi palsko _k_askāt_r_a waiptā_r\ aunt_r_a makatsi ///

Translation

b5. Additions according to [[TochSprR(B) I]]: II, 15 fn. 11 and 12 based on [[THT 10]] a1.
b6. Additions according to [[TochSprR(B) I]]: II, 16 fn. 1 based on [[THT 10]] a2.

General remarks

Includes strophes 7c-18c of the Tṛṣṇāvarga (III) and directly continues [[THT 8]], but considering the small size of the fragment – two thirds of the leaf are missing – and the complexity of the subject matter – it is a description of the Aśubhabhāvanā, i.e. meditation on the impurity or the abomination of the body – much remains unclear and uncertain, and the translation must be taken as an attempt only.The German translation in [[TochSprR(B) I]]: 16 quotes Abhidhk VI 10a-b as a reference for ease of understanding.

a1 not passion and ignorance, and then (they asked): [7c] existence... (7) ... a2 how are you able to inhibit the power of passion? [8b] Four ... a3 [8d] The body has to be seen as loathsome[ness], the Aśubha-[meditation] must constantly be observed ... a4 By the practitioners the elements [of the body] have be seen [as] six-fold a5 [9d] (it dwells) only in such droplets. [10b] Nine to ten days he lies down ... a6 the (elements) [are] stuck together and all pores [are] shut. [11a] By the mother the semen ... a7 ... like turned between two fires the suffering one dwells. [11d] Worms ... a8 having seen through the skin, the house of bones through the flesh. [12c] ... b1 the body (they turn) now, so that the wise see the (head) ... [13b] b2 depressed. [13d] Those who [are] restless, the self of these (thy raise?) up earlier ... b3 to pull the mind first towards the face. [14c] (On) the forehead between the brows ... b4 the woman, however, clung to the face of the man. [15b] Thereupon ... b5 (to recognize them one after the other). (Those) beings (that are good in evoking the Aśubha[-meditations]), the Yogins, are named in three ways [16a] b6 (As far as the Ādikārmikas [are concerned], these) dignified ones (are [named] in three ways). [16c] Some [have] the wish to see far, others [16d] ... b7 swollen, rotten, void of colour [17c] b8 [18b] (But if) the one who's mind is scattered and begins to run ...

Translations from [[Schmidt KT 1974]]

b4 ... die Frau hingegen hing an der Gestalt des Mannes. 108
The original manuscript is missing, but was the left side (about 1/4) of leaf 42 to the schnurloch.
